results.title: Tech Companies, New and Old, Clamor to Entice Cloud Computing Experts
results.abstract: As some tech sectors show signs of slowing, cloud services have created remarkable demand for highly educated engineers and mathematicians. And they are being compensated very well.

multimedia.caption: Tom Chavez runs Krux, a cloud-based data-management firm. Many of his employees are the kind of people tech giants seek.

results.title: Supreme Court Declines to Hear Apple’s Appeal in E-Book Pricing Case
results.abstract: Apple had wanted to appeal a lower court’s determination that it and five publishers had conspired to raise e-book prices above Amazon’s standard.

results.title: Taking Baby Steps Toward Software That Reasons Like Humans
results.abstract: A number of start-ups are developing a new generation of pattern recognition software that is slowly and steadily advancing artificial intelligence.

multimedia.caption: Richard Socher, founder and chief executive of MetaMind, a start-up developing artificial intelligence software.
Richard Socher, founder and chief executive of MetaMind, a start-up developing artificial intelligence software.

results.title: Smart Robots Make Strides, but There’s No Need to Flee Just Yet
results.abstract: Although fears of a computer-spawned apocalypse, stoked by grim predictions of some scientists, began decades ago, the current state of machines may offer reassurance.

results.title: Raymond Tomlinson, Who Put the @ Sign in Email, Is Dead at 74
results.abstract: The computer programmer chose the @ sign to separate a user name from a destination address to modify a messaging program.

multimedia.caption: “I’m often asked, did I know what I was doing? And the answer is, yes, I knew exactly what I was doing. I just had no notion whatsoever of what the ultimate impact would be,” Raymond Tomlinson said of his idea.
multimedia.copyright: Raytheon BBN Technologies, via Associated Press

results.title: Microsoft to Close 2 Game Development Studios
results.abstract: The studios are Lionhead, which is based in Britain, and Press Play, which is based in Denmark.

results.title: Microsoft Opens Its Corporate Data Software to Linux
results.abstract: For the first time, Microsoft is enabling SQL Server, its software for managing business data, to run on a competing operating system.

results.title: Verizon Settles With F.C.C. Over Hidden Tracking
results.abstract: The hidden tracking technology, called “supercookies,” was used for targeted advertising without customers’ permission.

results.title: Counting Characters in Twitter
results.abstract: There is a reason Twitter allows 20 fewer characters in a post than a standard SMS text message.

results.title: Tech Giants Battle for Top Cloud Talent
results.abstract: Industry titans like Amazon and Oracle are duking it out for cloud engineers, taking swipes at the competition and attracting workers with salaries as high as $1 million.

results.title: New Federal Website Aims to Enhance Community Services
results.abstract: Opportunity.census.gov will bring together data from several agencies in the hope of giving cities insights into how to provide children with better opportunities.

multimedia.caption: President Obama in Milwaukee last week. On Monday, his administration will launch the website Opportunity.census.gov.

results.abstract: Companies are employing their own custom-made images on social media; one even encoded an entire news release.

results.title: Wary of Digital Guests, Brooklyn House Tour Closes Its Doors
results.abstract: After three decades of providing glimpses into impressive homes, a Brooklyn Heights group canceled its house tour amid concerns about online exposure.

results.title: Europe’s Antitrust Enforcer on Google, Apple and the Year Ahead
results.abstract: In an interview, Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s competition commissioner, discusses the issues underpinning her current investigations and whether she unfairly targets American companies.

results.title: Competing Interests on Encryption Divide Top Obama Officials
results.abstract: While the White House denies any internal disagreement over its legal battle with Apple, the differences in the administration have become increasingly apparent.

results.title: It’s Discounted, but Is It a Deal? How List Prices Lost Their Meaning
results.abstract: When the same skillet costs $200 at a dozen web stores, the bargain isn’t so obvious to consumers, and scrutiny of this practice is growing.

results.title: Silicon Valley Has Not Saved Us From a Productivity Slowdown
results.abstract: New research questions the notion, popular in tech circles, that the benefits of technology are making up for mediocre gains in productivity and wages.

results.title: Hulk Hogan’s Suit Over Sex Tape May Test Limits of Online Press Freedom
results.abstract: Arguments in the jury trial start Monday in a case the celebrity wrestler says is about privacy, but the defendant, Gawker, argues is about the First Amendment.

results.title: Legal Briefs Flood in to Support Apple
results.abstract: The arguments differed in interesting ways, but the main message was the same: We side with Apple.

results.title: Facebook, in Accounting Change, Could Pay Millions More in British Taxes
results.abstract: The company will report sales linked to its British operations, mostly digital advertising, through its local subsidiary rather than its Irish unit.

multimedia.caption: As part of Facebook’s new tax structure, the social network said it would report sales linked to its British operations, primarily from digital advertising, through its local subsidiary, instead of booking its British revenues through its Irish unit.

results.title: Giving an Android App Permission to Play
results.abstract: Google’s Android 6.0 operating system, known as Marshmallow, gives its users control over their apps.

results.title: Checking the Graphics Card Specifications on Your Computer
results.abstract: If you have no idea what kind of graphics card is under the hood of your computer — PC or Mac — there is an easy way to find out.

results.title: Keeping Track of Windows Updates
results.abstract: You can see what software and security patches Microsoft has pushed out to your PC by looking in the Windows Update history.

results.title: Making the Mac Ignore Those Phone Calls
results.abstract: Apple’s Continuity software makes it easy to get iPhone calls on your Mac and other iOS devices, but you can turn it off.
